sentences.text: We propose a novel step toward the unsupervised seg-mentation of whole objects by combining '' hints '' of partial scene segmentation offered by multiple soft , binary mattes .
These mattes are implied by a set of hypothesized object boundary fragments in the scene .
Rather than trying to find or define a single '' best '' segmentation , we generate multiple segmentations of an image .

This reflects contemporary methods for unsupervised object discovery from groups of images , and it allows us to define intuitive evaluation met-rics for our sets of segmentations based on the accurate and parsimonious delineation of scene objects .
Our proposed approach builds on recent advances in spectral clustering , image matting , and boundary detection .
It is demonstrated qualitatively and quantitatively on a dataset of scenes and is suitable for current work in unsupervised object discovery without top-down knowledge .

kg2text: Our proposed approach builds on partial scene segmentation, which is offered by multiple soft, binary mattes. This approach combines a novel step that integrates hints from partial scene segmentation. Contemporary methods for unsupervised object discovery encompass a broader term that includes contemporary methods for unsupervised object discovery from groups of images. These methods reflect the use of multiple segmentations, which are essential for identifying objects without requiring labeled data. Multiple soft, binary mattes are implied by hypothesized object boundary fragments, while partial scene segmentation is a broader term that includes segmentation. Additionally, multiple soft, binary mattes fall under the broader category of mattes. Unsupervised object discovery without top-down knowledge is suitable for contemporary methods for unsupervised object discovery, which in turn is a broader term for unsupervised object discovery. Furthermore, contemporary methods for unsupervised object discovery from groups of images allow for the generation of sets of segmentations. Our proposed approach also builds on recent advances in spectral clustering, boundary detection, and image matting, all of which contribute to the effectiveness of unsupervised object discovery.

Unsupervised object discovery without top-down knowledge is a method that falls under the broader category of unsupervised object discovery, which aims to identify and segment objects in images without labeled training data. This process involves generating multiple segmentations of an image, which are produced as part of an unsupervised segmentation approach that utilizes hints from partial scene segmentations. These segmentations are based on accurate and parsimonious delineation of scene objects, which refers to the precise identification of distinct visual elements within a scene. Hypothesized object boundary fragments play a crucial role in this context, as they suggest the boundaries of objects within a scene. Our proposed approach builds on recent advances in spectral clustering, leveraging these techniques to enhance the segmentation process. The effectiveness of this approach is demonstrated on a dataset of scenes, which serves as a collection of images used for evaluating the segmentation quality. Overall, the generation of multiple segmentations facilitates a deeper understanding of scene objects, moving beyond the concept of a single 'best' segmentation.
